title: How to Make Savoury Scones

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 180C / 350F.
steps.description: Grease your baking tray / cookie sheet.

steps.headline: Mix the flour, salt and butter in a bowl.
steps.description: Use a pair or butter knives,  your fingers or a pastry whisk, blend them until they form a breadcrumb-like consistency. You can also but them in a bowl of a food processor which can be much quicker and certainly easier. An electric mixer is fine but is slower.

steps.headline: Add the cheese and any other additional variations (don't add the milk just yet).
steps.description: Fold these through to an even consistency.

steps.headline: Add the milk and stir using a knife until they form together, be gentle as too much firmness will result in tough scones.
When it has mostly come together into large clumps, tip the mix onto a clean, lightly floured surface.
Knead very gently until it comes together and pat into a layer approx 3 and a 1/2 centimetres or 1.5 inches thick.
steps.description: Cut with a sharp knife into even sized squares, wedges or diamonds, or use a scone cutter. If using a scone cutter, it is recommended to press down, instead of pressing and twisting at the same time. This often helps then to rise evenly.

steps.headline: Place fairly closely together on the baking tray and glaze with the milk or beaten egg.
steps.description: Bake approx 20 minutes or until golden. Serve immediately with butter, sour cream or soup.

text: Preheat your oven to 180C / 350F. Grease your baking tray / cookie sheet. Mix the flour, salt and butter in a bowl. Use a pair or butter knives,  your fingers or a pastry whisk, blend them until they form a breadcrumb-like consistency. You can also but them in a bowl of a food processor which can be much quicker and certainly easier. An electric mixer is fine but is slower. Add the cheese and any other additional variations (don't add the milk just yet). Fold these through to an even consistency. Add the milk and stir using a knife until they form together, be gentle as too much firmness will result in tough scones.  When it has mostly come together into large clumps, tip the mix onto a clean, lightly floured surface.  Knead very gently until it comes together and pat into a layer approx 3 and a 1/2 centimetres or 1.5 inches thick. Cut with a sharp knife into even sized squares, wedges or diamonds, or use a scone cutter. If using a scone cutter, it is recommended to press down, instead of pressing and twisting at the same time. This often helps then to rise evenly. Place fairly closely together on the baking tray and glaze with the milk or beaten egg. Bake approx 20 minutes or until golden. Serve immediately with butter, sour cream or soup. Finished.
